awd_titl_txt: Theoretical Investigation of Low-Energy Positron and Positronium Collisions
awd_abstract_narration:
Vortices (or whirlpools) are familiar properties of fluids and gases and so are important in a number of fields of science and engineering, including fluid dynamics, astrophysics, condensed-matter physics and non-linear dynamics. They are examples of collective phenomena in stirred systems, and have even been observed in the ultracold atomic gases known as Bose-Einstein condensates. Surprisingly, vortices have recently been discovered in the quantum mechanical wave function describing elementary electron-atom collision processes, where their appearance was correlated to deep minima in observed scattering cross sections. The situation is still somewhat murky, since elementary collision processes seem to have little in common with the much more complex phenomena associated with the collective properties of liquids and gases. This project hopes to shed light on this mystery by searching for vortex formation in collision processes involving positrons rather than electrons. Positrons are antiparticles of electrons, carry positive charge, and so interact very differently with matter. Sensitivity to the charge of an incident projectile will therefore be tested through direct theoretical calculations, hopefully clarifying the underlying mechanism of vortex formation in these processes. Since positrons are now commonly used in a variety of fields and applications, ranging from condensed matter physics to positron-emission tomography (PET scans), the relevance of vortex formation to elementary collision processes involving positrons could have wide-ranging impact.  The work will engage graduate students in challenging research projects involving elementary quantum mechanical collision processes.

Recently, researchers have demonstrated that vortex formation is responsible for deep minima observed in the experimental measurements of the triply differential cross sections for electron-impact ionization of helium atoms. Vortices have also been studied for other ionization processes in atomic collisions. The first goal of this project is to analyze vortex formation in positron-hydrogen and positron-helium collisions, to see whether or not vortices affect the rate of positronium formation. The PI will guide a graduate student through a detailed analysis of positronium formation in these processes using Kohn-type variational methods, multichannel effective range theories and the Born approximation. The goal is to determine basic components necessary to obtain a zero in the positronium formation scattering amplitude, the corresponding deep minimum in the differential cross section and the vortex in the velocity field that corresponds to the scattering amplitude. A second project is to study positronium-positronium scattering, which is of interest since it is a fundamental four-body Coulomb problem, and in support of experimental efforts to make a positronium Bose-Einstein Condensate. The PI will train a graduate student to use Kohn-type variational methods and the Born approximation with exchange for this analysis. A goal is to obtain benchmark results for ground-state positronium - ground-state positronium scattering using Kohn-type variational methods.

por.por_cntn:
Vortices are of interest in many areas of physics including condensed matter, astrophysics and atomic physics. Previously, Macek and co-workers interpreted a deep minimum in the experimental measured triply differential cross section of electron-helium ionization in terms of a vortex in the velocity field associated with the ionization amplitude.

My former graduate student Dr. Albandari Alrowaily, my international research collaborator Dr. Peter Van Reeth (University College London, UK) and I obtained deep minima in the differential cross section for positronium formation in positron-hydrogen collisions in the energy range of the Ore gap. We connected each minimum to a vortex in the extended velocity field that is associated with the positronium formation scattering amplitude.  Our work of deep minimum and vortices for positronium formation in positron-hydrogen collisions was published in 2019 in Journal of Physics B.

Helium is more accessible to measurements of positronium formation than is atomic hydrogen. We obtained a deep minimum in the positronium formation differential cross section for positron-helium collisions which we connected to a vortex in the extended velocity field that is associated with the positronium-formation scattering amplitude. We also obtained a minimum in the forward-direction positronium-formation differential cross section for positron-helium collisions. We published our work in 2021 in the journal Atoms. Dr. Gaetana (Nella) Laricchia's positron experimental group reported measurements of the absolute positronium formation differential cross section in the near-forward direction for a number of gases including helium. For neon, argon and xenon a dip is present in the experimental results of the near-forward direction differential positronium formation cross section. A minimum was not obtained in the experimental results of the near-forward direction cross section for helium. However, the experimental measurements for helium were made at a higher energy than what we considered in our calculations.

Few-body Coulomb systems are of fundamental interest in atomic physics. A UNT graduate student, Mr. Gabriel Medrano, under my supervision determined the bound-state energy of Ps2. This work was done in collaboration with Dr. Peter Van Reeth. Mr. Medrano used a highly correlated Hylleraas-type wave function. Interestingly, he found that a bound state of Ps2 is obtained considering only the direct term in the trial wave function.  He also considered both positron and electron exchange. A manuscript on the energy of the bound-state of Ps2 is in preparation, but it has not been completed.

A graduate student Mr. Cody DeMars used the Coulomb-Born approximation to compute the triply differential cross section for electron- and positron-impact ionization of helium. He obtained deep minima in the cross section and compared the Coulomb-Born electron-helium cross sections with experimental measurements. Mr. DeMars, a former undergraduate student Mr. Jesse Kent and myself are the authors of an European Physical Journal D paper that presents this work.

Mr. DeMars also used the Coulomb-Born approximation to compute the triply differential cross section for electron- and positron-impact ionization of atomic hydrogen. Within the Coulomb-Born approximation a deep minima is present in the cross section for each projectile. Mr. DeMars computed the velocity field associated with a quantity called the transition matrix element. He found that the velocity field rotates around the zero in this quantity. Interestingly, a deep minimum is not present in the time-dependent close coupling calculation of the triply differential cross section of electron-hydrogen ionization performed by Dr. James Colgan (Los Alamos National Laboratory). It is also not present in the three-body distorted-wave  cross section computed by Dr. Sadek Amami and Dr. Don Madison (Missouri University of Science and Technology). Mr. Cody DeMars, Dr. James Colgan, Dr. Sadek Amami, Dr. Don Madison and I published our work in the journal Atoms.

The research has been presented at conferences. 

I am a female full professor in the Physics Department of the University of North Texas, which is a Hispanic Serving Institution and a Tier One Research Institution. 

I mentored graduate students during the period of my NSF grant (September 1, 2017 to August 31, 2021). One of these graduate students, a female,  graduated with her Ph.D. in May 2021.

Ward is my maiden name that I primarily use for research whereas Quintanilla is my married name.
